node.html:
Choose a New York Times article and select a few sentences or a paragraph to represent its story. Then make three ‘different’ compositions for mobile (375 × 812px), desktop (1440×900px), and print (8.5 × 11 in). The compositions must use only b&w type (no images or graphic shapes).

Use Figma for the screen, and Indesign for the print. In the end of the class, you will share how you used typesetting principles and grid system for each composition.

How can a static text take a temporal form? Typography has a close relationship with the evolution of tools and platforms. As nowadays screens, browsers, and mobile have been replacing static matters, presentations of typography also has became more active and reactive. In this project, we will explore ways of expressing a text within time-based framework such as interactive, video, audio, installation, or performance. In this process, we will focus on how the transformation of the text can influence to its original meaning.

Assignment
Select a text from below and excerpt a sentence or a few words, and express it through the media that described above. The text must present at least 3 different changes, and the changes should be applied through a theme as a cohesive visual direction, more than a few elements on the design.
Things to consider
  • A theme of changes: could be (but not limited to) — time, speed, rhythm, repetition, sequences, order, repetition, translation, voice, (more to come depending on the textlist)
  • Trigger to make changes: time, mouse events(hover, click, scroll, etc), browser size, etc.
  • Elements to be changed : font, scale, color, content, location, voice, hierarchy, etc.
Schedule
  • 09/12/19: Bring 2-3 different design directions based on the chosen text. Each direction, present visual design sketches (a PSD file, jpeg, pdf, illustrator or Sketch file) that illustrates different stages of changes. You should be able to explain how your motion strategy is related to the context of its reading experience.
  • 09/19/19: Final crit
